titlepage.titleproper:
Finding aid for
Edward Pierce Papers, 1960s-1987 and 1996
titlepage.author:
Finding aid created by
Polly Reynolds, November 2005

did.abstract: Dr. Edward Pierce was active in both medicine and politics in Michigan. He was well-known for his conception of and work at the Summit Medical Center in Ann Arbor, Michigan, a center offering medical services for low-income individuals. His political career included a seat on the Ann Arbor City Council, a term as Michigan State Senator and Mayor of Ann Arbor. The papers relate primarily to his political career, with the bulk of the papers focusing on his term as mayor of Ann Arbor from 1985 to 1987. Other papers refer to his campaigns for Congress, Senate, and governor.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: Mayoral records donated by Dr. Pierce, April 1987 (Donor no. 7436); Additional records (primarily pre-mayoral) donated September 2005 by Judge Lynne Pierce (Donor no. 9647)

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Edward Pierce Papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Dr. Edward Pierce was born in Three Rivers, Michigan on January 3, 1930 and settled in Ann Arbor in 1940. Receiving both his Bachelor's degree (in 1955) and his Medical degree (in 1959) from the University of Michigan, Dr. Edward Pierce set up a family practice in Ann Arbor in 1960. Dr. Pierce was well-known for his conception of and work at the Summit Medical Center Medical Center in Ann Arbor, a center offering medical services for low-income individuals. From 1974 to 1975 and 1989 to 1990 he was the Chairman of the Department of Family Practice at St. Joseph Mercy Hospital. In 1996, Dr. Pierce began Merian's Friends, a physician-aid-in-dying group.

He also was active in politics as well, first serving on the Ann Arbor City Council from 1964 to 1966, a term as Michigan State Senator in 1979, and mayor of Ann Arbor from 1985 to 1987. In 1974 and 1976, he ran for Congress, but lost. In 1982, he ran for Michigan governor in the Democratic primary, losing to James Blanchard.
Dr. Pierce passed away on July 4, 2002.

scopecontent.p: Dr. Pierce's papers relate primarily to his political career, with the bulk of the papers focusing on his term as Mayor of Ann Arbor from 1985 to 1987. Other papers document his campaigns for Congress, Senate, and governor.
The papers are divided into five series: Pre-Mayoral files, Mayoral files, Post-Mayoral files, Photographs, and Sound Recordings.

The Pre-Mayoral series (0.5 linear ft., 1960-1987) documents Pierce's campaigns for Congress, Senate, governor and mayor as well as other political campaigns. The papers primarily include position papers, speeches, interviews, and correspondence.

The Mayoral papers (5 linear ft., 1985-1987) include subject files on municipal administration, correspondence with residents, proclamations, resident complaint file, appointment books and calendar, and photographs.

did.unittitle: Letters to University of Michigan athletes

scopecontent.p: The Post-Mayoral series (0.1 linear ft., 1996) contains a file on Merian's Friends, a physician-aid-in-dying group that Dr. Pierce founded in 1996. The file mainly includes information and newsletters about the group and some photographs.
The Photographs series (0.1 linear ft.) includes photographs and visual materials covering his mayoral period and photographs of portraits and campaigns.
The Sound Recordings series (0.1 linear ft., 1974-1984) contains three audiocassettes of Pierce speaking on issues for various political campaigns.

relatedmaterial.head: Related material
relatedmaterial.p: Researchers interested in Dr. Pierce's medical career may want to consult the Summit Medical Center records at the Bentley Historical Library. More extensive documentation relating to Dr. Pierce's congressional, senatorial, and gubernatorial campaigns can be found in the papers of Robert Alexander, a campaign worker for Edward Pierce.
